title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Synaptic Communication
Neurons transmit information to other neurons and target cells using specialized compartments called Synapses. A Synapse is a specialized junction where a neuron communicates with another neuron (or another cell).

IMPORTANT: In synapses, neurons are not physically continous, but there is a gap called Synaptic Cleft




Three main components:

Presynaptic compartment (or terminal)
Synaptic cleft

Postsynaptic compartment (or spine)




Synapses allow:

Directional signaling

Signal modulation

Integration of multiple inputs

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. What Is Neuroscience?


Neuroscience asks a simple question:
How does the brain produce behavior?

Studies the Central (brain and spinal cord) and Peripheral (somatic, autonomic and enteric) nervous systems

Connects biology, psychology, physics, engineering, and philosophy

Goal of this course: build intuition about how the nervous system works, without assuming prior biology knowledge.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. What Is a Neuron?


Neurons are the basic units of the brain.
Their main function is to send electrical signals over short and long distances.
They are electrically and chemically excitable. The function of a neuron depends on its structure.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Major Parts of the Neuron



Dendrites

Cell body (soma)
Axon hillock
Axon
Presynaptic terminal These components determine how signals are received, processed, and transmitted.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Diagram: Typical Neuron


A neuron has:
- Branching dendrites
- A soma with nucleus
- A long axon
- Terminal branches forming synapses

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Dendrites



Branch out from the soma

Primary targets of incoming signals

The number of dendrites influences how many inputs the neuron can receive

Often contain spines, which increase surface area for synaptic contact

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Cell Body (Soma)



Contains nucleus and organelles

Integrates incoming signals from dendrites

Biochemistry of the cell shapes its excitability and response properties

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Axon Hillock



Junction between soma and axon

Location where action potentials are initiated

Sensitive to the summed electrical inputs from dendrites and soma

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. The Axon



Conducts electrical signals over long distances

May be myelinated to increase conduction speed

Can branch extensively

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Presynaptic Terminal



End of the axon

Releases neurotransmitter onto postsynaptic cells

Forms multiple terminals for communication with many neurons

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Neurons Communicate Electrically and Chemically

Electrical signals travel along the axon.

Chemical signals (neurotransmitters) are released at the synapse.

This dual mode of signaling enables fast and flexible communication.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Structure Influences Function


Examples: - More dendrites → more inputs
- Axon myelination → faster conduction
- Terminal branching → more downstream targets
Form and function are tightly linked in neuronal physiology.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Neuron Diversity (Overview)
Neurons vary in:

Size

Shape

Dendritic complexity

Axon length

Neurotransmitter type

This diversity supports specialized functions across the nervous system.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. Summary of Key Concepts

Neurons are the fundamental signaling units of the nervous system

Structure determines function

Signals are electrical within neurons and chemical between them

Dendrites receive, soma integrates, axon transmits, terminals communicate

text:

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Ion Movement


Neurons communicate using electrical signals.
These signals exist because ions move across cell membranes.
Understanding ion movement is the foundation for:

Electrical signaling
Membrane potential
Action potentials
Synaptic transmission

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. What Is an Ion?


An ion is an atom or molecule with an electrical charge.

Positive charge → cation

Negative charge → anion

In neuroscience, the most important ions are:

Sodium (Na⁺)
Potassium (K⁺)
Chloride (Cl⁻)
Calcium (Ca²⁺)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: 2. Why Charges Matter in the Brain
text:
2. Why Charges Matter in the Brain
Electrical signals arise because:

Ions carry charge
Neurons separate charges across membranes
Differences in charge create electrical forces


No electricity → no neural signaling.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. The Neuronal Membrane


The neuron is surrounded by a lipid bilayer membrane.
Key properties:

Electrically insulating
Impermeable to most ions

This separation is essential for signaling.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Ion Channels


Ion channels are proteins embedded in the membrane.
They:

Allow specific ions to cross
Are selective (not all ions can pass)
Can open or close


Ion movement only occurs through these channels.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Channel Selectivity


Ion channels are selective because:

Ions differ in size
Ions differ in charge
Channel pores are highly specific

Example:

Sodium channels allow Na⁺ but not K⁺
Potassium channels allow K⁺ but not Na⁺

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Two Forces Acting on Ions
Ion movement depends on two forces:

Diffusion

Electrical attraction or repulsion


The combined effect determines ion flow.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Diffusion


Diffusion is movement from:





flowchart LR
  A[High concentration]
  B[Low concentration]

  A -->|Net flow| B
  B -. No net flow .-> A
  style A fill:#2b2b2b,stroke:#67bdfb,color:#e6e6e6
  style B fill:#2b2b2b,stroke:#67bdfb,color:#e6e6e6
  linkStyle default stroke:#bbbbbb,stroke-width:2px






If more Na⁺ ions are outside the neuron than inside, Na⁺ tends to move inward.

It does not require energy.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Electrical Forces


Charged particles are influenced by:

Opposite charges attract
Same charges repel

A negatively charged interior attracts positive ions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Electrochemical Gradient
The electrochemical gradient combines:

Chemical gradient (diffusion)
Electrical gradient (charge)

Ion movement depends on both at the same time.
This is the key principle of neural signaling.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Example: Sodium Ions (Na⁺)
Typically:

High Na⁺ outside the neuron
Low Na⁺ inside
Inside of neuron is negatively charged


Both diffusion and electrical forces push Na⁺ inward.


The inside of the neuron (and cells in general) is negative mainly because of large amount of anions inside the cell like proteins and other large organic anions (phosphates, metabolites).

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Example: Potassium Ions (K⁺)

High K⁺ inside the neuron
Low K⁺ outside
Electrical force pulls K⁺ inward
Diffusion pushes K⁺ outward


Here the diffusion force in higher that the electical force an K⁺ flux tends to go outward

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Equilibrium Potential
The equilibrium potential is the membrane voltage at which:

Electrical force exactly balances diffusion
No net movement of an ion occurs

Each ion has its own equilibrium potential.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Important Concept
Different ions want to move in different directions.
Neural electrical signals emerge from:

Which channels are open
Which ions can move
The direction of ion flow

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Example: Calcium Ions (Ca²⁺)

Very low concentration inside neurons
Strong positive electrical charge
Acts as both an ion and a signaling molecule


Opening Ca²⁺ channels causes a inward flux of Ca²⁺ ions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Ion Movement Is Passive
Ion movement through channels:

Does not require energy
Is driven by electrochemical gradients


But maintaining the gradients require energy! The gradients are maintained by specific proteins called pumps that can move ions against their gradients.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Membrane Voltage


The neuron’s membrane separates electrical charges.
This separation creates a quantity called membrane voltage.

Voltage is a difference in electrical potential
It tells us how strong the electrical force is
It is measured across the membrane, not inside the cell


Voltage is not a substance and not a force.
It is a measure of how much electrical energy is available to move ions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Equilibrium Potential (Formal Definition)
The equilibrium potential of an ion is:

The membrane voltage at which there is no net movement of that ion across the membrane.

Important points:

It depends on concentration differences
It depends on charge

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. The Nernst Equation
To describe equilibrium quantitatively, we use the Nernst equation.
It links:

ion concentration differences
electrical voltage across the membrane

\[
E_{\mathrm{ion}} = \frac{RT}{zF}\ln\left(\frac{[\mathrm{ion}]_{\mathrm{out}}}{[\mathrm{ion}]_{\mathrm{in}}}\right)
\]

\(E_{\mathrm{ion}}\): equilibrium potential of the ion

\(R\): gas constant

\(T\): absolute temperature

\(z\): ion charge (valence)

\(F\): Faraday constant

section: 2. What the Equation Means (Not How to Use It)
text:
2. What the Equation Means (Not How to Use It)
You do not need to memorize this formula.
What matters is what it tells us:

Larger concentration differences → larger equilibrium voltage
Higher charge → stronger electrical effect
Each ion has its own equilibrium potential


The term (z) is the ion’s charge:

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
section: 2. From Equilibrium Potential to Membrane Potential
text:
2. From Equilibrium Potential to Membrane Potential
So far we have described equilibrium for one ion at a time.
Real neurons are a bit different:

Multiple ion species are present
Multiple channels are open simultaneously

The membrane voltage reflects the combined effect of all ions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. What Is the Membrane Potential?

The membrane potential is: The electrical potential difference between the inside and the outside of the cell membrane. It is measured in millivolts (mV), 1 mV = 0.001 Volts (V).

Each ion has:

Its own equilibrium potential
Its own concentration gradient

But the membrane potential is:

Not equal to \(E_{\mathrm{Na}}\)
Not equal to \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\)
Not equal to \(E_{\mathrm{Cl}}\)
It lies between them.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Which Ion Dominates?
The influence of an ion depends on:

Permeability, a measure of how easily a given ion can cross the membrane through its channels and is given by the number of ions for that channel are open.

At rest, neuronal membranes are:

Highly permeable to \(K^+\)
Weakly permeable to \(Na^+\)
Moderately permeable to \(Cl^-\)


In most neurons resting membrane potential is \(\approx -65\,\mathrm{mV}\). This reflects potassium dominance at rest.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Voltage Change
If channels open for an ion, the membrane potential changes. If a positive ion moves inside the cell, the membrane potential becomes less negative; if it moves outside, it becomes more negative. For negative ions, the effect is reversed.



Example: Opening Sodium Channels
If \(Na^+\) channels open:

\(Na^+\) enters the cell
Membrane potential becomes less negative

This process is called depolarization.



Example: Opening Potassium Channels
If \(K^+\) channels open:

\(K^+\) leaves the cell
Membrane potential becomes more negative

This process is called hyperpolarization.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. The Goldman–Hodgkin–Katz Equation
When multiple ions contribute to the membrane voltage, the membrane potential is given by the Goldman–Hodgkin–Katz (GHK) equation:
\[
V_m =
\frac{RT}{F}
\ln\!\left(
\frac{
P_{\mathrm{K}}[K^+]_{\mathrm{out}} +
P_{\mathrm{Na}}[Na^+]_{\mathrm{out}} +
P_{\mathrm{Cl}}[Cl^-]_{\mathrm{in}}
}{
P_{\mathrm{K}}[K^+]_{\mathrm{in}} +
P_{\mathrm{Na}}[Na^+]_{\mathrm{in}} +
P_{\mathrm{Cl}}[Cl^-]_{\mathrm{out}}
}
\right)
\]



\(V_m\) is the membrane potential

\(P_{\mathrm{K}}, P_{\mathrm{Na}}, P_{\mathrm{Cl}}\) are permeabilities

\([\cdot]_{\mathrm{in}}\) and \([\cdot]_{\mathrm{out}}\) are ion concentrations

\(R\), \(T\), and \(F\) have the same meaning as in the Nernst equation



If only one ion is permeable: Goldman reduces to Nernst



You may notice that:

\([Cl^-]_{\mathrm{in}}\) appears in the numerator
\([Cl^-]_{\mathrm{out}}\) appears in the denominator

This happens because:

Chloride carries a negative charge
Its electrical force acts in the opposite direction

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. From Steady Voltage to Signals
Neurons use changes in membrane potential as signals.
These changes can be:

Small or large (millivolts )
Slow or fast (milliseconds)
Local or long-range (micrometers to meters)


Two main types exist:

Graded potentials
Action potentials

They differ in origin, size, and function.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Graded Potentials

Graded potential: local change in membrane potential whose magnitude depends on the strength of the stimulus.



Key properties:

Amplitude varies continuously
Can be depolarizing or hyperpolarizing
Spread passively
Become smaller with distance



This decay is due to:

Membrane resistance
Cytoplasmic resistance



They are common in:

Dendrites
Soma

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Integration of Graded Potentials


Multiple graded potentials can:

Add together in space (spatial summation)
Add together in time (temporal summation)

Integration mainly occurs at:

The cell body
The axon initial segment (axon hillock)


Neurons continuously integrate incoming signals.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Action Potentials


If depolarization is strong enough:

A critical voltage is reached
A different electrical event is triggered

This voltage is called the threshold. Potentials beyond the threshold trigger Action Potentials.

Action potential: A large, rapid, and stereotyped change in membrane potential, originated at the level of the axon hillock, that propagates along the axon.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Why Action Potentials Are Needed



Graded potentials decay with distance.

To communicate over long axons, neurons need:

A signal that does not fade
A reliable, all-or-none event

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Membrane Proteins and Transport
The lipid bilayer is electrically insulating. Ions can cross the membrane only through membrane proteins.
Membrane transport proteins fall into two broad categories:

Channels
Transporters (carriers and pumps)


Ion channel: A protein that forms a continuous aqueous pathway across the membrane, allowing ions to move down their electrochemical gradient.
Properties:

Do not use metabolic energy (passive)
Do not move ions against gradients (no energy)
Selective to specific Ions

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Channel Gating


Ion channels are not static holes.
They fluctuate between:

Closed states
Open states


Channels can be gated by different physical signals:

Chemical binding (ligand-gated - e.g. Neurotransmitters)
Mechanical deformation (mechanosensitive)
Membrane voltage (voltage-gated - activated when the membrane cross a specific voltage)




Gating: The process by which an ion channel switches between open and closed states.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Graded Potentials and Channels
During Graded Potentials:

Passive channels remain unchanged
Voltage-gated channels remain mostly closed


Voltage changes are passive and proportional to input and decay over space-time.

When depolarization is small:

A few voltage-gated \(Na^+\) channels open
Resulting \(Na^+\) influx is weak
Passive \(K^+\) currents counteract depolarization

The voltage relaxes back to rest.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Threshold Crossing
At threshold:

Voltage-gated \(Na^+\) channel opening becomes significant
\(Na^+\) influx exceeds opposing currents
Depolarization accelerates

This marks the transition from passive to active behavior.

Once threshold is crossed:

Many \(Na^+\) channels open rapidly
Membrane permeability to \(Na^+\) increases sharply
Voltage changes are no longer passive

The action potential is initiated.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. During the Action Potential


During the spike:

Voltage-gated \(Na^+\) channels open, then inactivate
Voltage-gated \(K^+\) channels open with delay

Voltage is dominated by voltage-gated dynamics.
After the action potential:

\(Na^+\) channels recover from inactivation
\(K^+\) channels close
Passive channels dominate again









Inactivation: A state in which a voltage-gated channel is closed and temporarily unable to reopen, even though the membrane is still depolarized.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Refractory Period


After an action potential, the neuron cannot immediately fire another spike.

Refractory period: A time interval following an action potential during which the neuron’s ability to generate another action potential is reduced or absent.

This phase is caused purely by Na⁺ channel inactivation.
Refractory periods ensure that:

Action potentials propagate in one direction
Spikes are separated in time (neural code)
Maximum firing frequency is limited

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Axon Diameter and Conduction Speed
The speed of action potential propagation depends on axon geometry.
Larger axons:

Have lower internal (axial) resistance
Allow local currents to spread more easily
Depolarize adjacent membrane faster

As a result, action potentials propagate faster in thicker axons.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Myelination and Electrical Insulation
Many axons are wrapped in myelin, a multilayered insulating sheath formed by glial cells.
Myelination is not continuous along the axon.
Axons contain regularly spaced gaps called nodes of Ranvier.
At nodes:

The membrane is unmyelinated
Voltage-gated \(Na^+\) channels are highly concentrated
Action potentials are regenerated

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Saltatory Conduction
In myelinated axons:

Depolarization spreads passively under the myelin
Action potentials occur only at nodes
The signal appears to “jump” from node to node

This mode of propagation is called saltatory conduction. As a result, conduction speed increases dramatically. This is a physical optimization of signal transmission.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. In-Class Exercise — True or False
For each statement, decide whether it is True (T) or False (F).

The lipid bilayer by itself allows ions to cross the membrane easily.

Ion channels consume energy to move ions across the membrane.

Diffusion and electrical forces always act in the same direction.

Each ion has its own equilibrium potential.

The membrane potential is usually equal to one specific equilibrium potential.

Graded potentials decrease in amplitude as they spread.

Action potentials require voltage-gated ion channels.

Sodium channel inactivation is responsible for the refractory period.

Increasing axon diameter increases conduction speed.

In myelinated axons, action potentials occur at nodes of Ranvier only.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. In-Class Exercise - Answers

False - the lipid bilayer is electrically insulating to ions.

False - ion channels are passive; pumps consume energy.

False - diffusion and electrical forces can oppose each other.

True - equilibrium potential depends on ion charge and concentrations.

False - membrane potential reflects multiple ions and permeabilities.

True - graded potentials spread passively and decay with distance.

True - voltage-gated channels are required for action potentials.

True - Na⁺ channel inactivation causes refractoriness.

True - larger diameter reduces axial resistance.

True - spikes are regenerated only at nodes in myelinated axons.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Why Synapses?

Action potentials propagate along a single neuron

Neurons are not physically continuous

Information must cross a cell-to-cell gap

Synapses allow:

Directional signaling

Signal modulation

Integration of multiple inputs

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Presynaptic Events



Action potential arrives at terminal
Membrane depolarization
Opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels
Ca²⁺ influx triggers vesicle fusion
Neurotransmitter released into synaptic cleft

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Synaptic Vesicles



Small membrane-bound organelles in the presynaptic terminal

Store neurotransmitters at high concentration

Cluster near active zones of the presynaptic membrane


Key properties:

Release occurs in discrete, quantal events
The release is mediated by SNARE proteins
Vesicles are recycled locally




Process:

SNAREs bring vesicle and presynaptic membranes close together

Ca²⁺ influx triggers final fusion step

Neurotransmitter released by exocytosis

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. The Nucleus and DNA



The nucleus contains the cell’s DNA
DNA is a long chain of nucleotides
Nucleotides form genes


Genes are instructions for building cellular components

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
1. From Genes to Proteins



Genes encode proteins
Proteins are chains of amino acids
The sequence of nucleotides determines:

The sequence of amino acids
The structure and function of the protein



Proteins are the working molecules of the cell

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Myelination


Many axons, especially long ones, are wrapped in myelin, a multilayered insulating sheath formed by glial cells. This ensures that the signal reaches its destination.
Myelination is not continuous along the axon. Axons contain regularly spaced gaps called nodes of Ranvier.

At nodes:

Voltage-gated \(Na^+\) and \(K^+\) channels are highly concentrated
Action potentials are regenerated
Saltatory conduction (the action potential jumps from one node to the other)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Postsynaptic Membrane


Contains neurotransmitter Receptors

Receptors can be of two main classes:

Ionotropic receptors

Ligand-gated ion channels
Fast responses

Metabotropic receptors

G-protein coupled
Slower but modulatory (long-lasting response)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Postsynaptic Potentials


Neurotransmitter binding produces grades signals of different types:

EPSP: excitatory postsynaptic potential
IPSP: inhibitory postsynaptic potential


Excitatory synapses:

Depolarize the membrane
Mediated by Ca²⁺ influx

Inhibitory synapses:

Hyperpolarize or stabilize membrane potential
Mediated by Cl⁻ influx

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Postsynaptic Events


Neurotransmitter binding produces graded signals of different types:

EPSP: Excitatory PostSynaptic Potential
IPSP: Inhibitory PostSynaptic Potential


Excitatory synapses:

Depolarize the membrane
Mediated by Na (or Ca²⁺ in special cases) influx

Inhibitory synapses:

Hyperpolarize or stabilize membrane potential
Mediated by Cl⁻ influx









Neurotransmitter action ends by:

Reuptake into presynaptic terminal
Enzymatic degradation

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Neurons transmit information to other neurons and target cells using specialized compartments called Synapses. A synapse is a specialized junction where a neuron communicates with another neuron (or another cell).

IMPORTANT: In synapses, neurons are not physically continous, but there is a gap called Synaptic Cleft





Synapses allow:

Directional signaling

Signal modulation

Integration of multiple inputs





Three main components:

Presynaptic compartment (or terminal)
Synaptic cleft

Postsynaptic compartment (or spine)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Neurotransmitters
Neurotransmitters are chemical messengers released at synapses
They transmit signals from a presynaptic neuron to a postsynaptic cell



Each neurotransmitter:

Is synthesized in the neuron
Is released in response to activity
Acts on specific receptors




Neurotransmitters can be grouped by function:

Excitatory
Inhibitory
Modulatory




The effect depends on the receptor, not only on the neurotransmitter

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Glutamate



Main excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain

Involved in:

Sensory processing
Learning and memory
Synaptic plasticity


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors
Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Glutamate (Glu)



Main excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain

Involved in:

Sensory processing
Learning and memory
Synaptic plasticity


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors
Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Glutamate - Glu



Main excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain


Increases neuronal excitability (EPSP)
Really abbundant in the brain


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors
Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. GABA



Main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain


Reduces neuronal excitability (IPSP)
Essential for network stability


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors (fast inhibition)
Metabotropic receptors (slow inhibition)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Acetylcholine



Acts in both central and peripheral nervous systems

Involved in:

Muscle contraction
Attention, Learning and Memory


Acts on:

Ionotropic receptors
Metabotropic receptors

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:

Acts as a Diffuse Projection System in the brain. This means that is produced in specific nuclei and projected throughout the brain. AKA: Cholinergic system

text:
2. Voltage Change
If channels open for an ion, the membrane potential changes. If a positive ion moves inside the cell, the membrane potential becomes less negative; if it moves outside, it becomes more negative. For negative ions, the effect is reversed.



Example: Opening Sodium Channels
If \(Na^+\) channels open:

\(Na^+\) enters the cell
Membrane potential becomes less negative

This process is called depolarization.



Example: Opening Potassium Channels
If \(K^+\) channels open:

\(K^+\) leaves the cell
Membrane potential becomes more negative

This process is called hyperpolarization.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
2. Graded Potentials

Graded potential: local change in membrane potential whose magnitude depends on the strength of the stimulus.



Key properties:

Amplitude varies continuously
Can be depolarizing or hyperpolarizing
Spread passively
Become smaller with distance



This decay is due to:

Membrane resistance
Cytoplasmic resistance



They are common in:

Dendrites
Soma

text:
3. Neurotransmitter Clearance
After release, neurotransmitters must be removed from the synaptic cleft
This ensures that synaptic signals are brief and precisely controlled

Reuptake

Neurotransmitter is transported back into the presynaptic terminal
Mediated by specific membrane transporters
Allows recycling of neurotransmitter molecules

Enzymatic Degradation

Neurotransmitter is broken down by enzymes in the synaptic cleft
Prevents prolonged receptor activation

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
3. Drugs and Neurotransmitter Clearance
Many drugs act by altering how neurotransmitters are removed from the synaptic cleft
By changing clearance, drugs modify the strength and duration of synaptic signaling.



Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs)

Block serotonin reuptake transporters
Increase serotonin availability at synapses

Used to treat:

Depression
Anxiety disorders

Effects develop slowly due to circuit-level adaptations



Cocaine

Blocks reuptake of:

Dopamine
Norepinephrine
Serotonin


Results in:

Strong increase in synaptic signaling
Enhanced reward and arousal
High addictive potential

text:
Synaptic Communication – True or False?

Synapses are points where neurons are physically continuous

Neurotransmitter effects depend only on the neurotransmitter released

Ionotropic receptors mediate fast synaptic responses

NMDA receptors are permeable to calcium ions

GABA-A receptors are excitatory ion channels

Monoamines mainly act as neuromodulators

Endocannabinoids are released from presynaptic terminals

Neurotransmitter clearance helps limit synaptic signal duration

SSRIs reduce serotonin levels in the synaptic cleft

Axo-axonic synapses can modulate neurotransmitter release

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Answers and Explanations

False - Neurons are not physically continuous at synapses; they are separated by the synaptic cleft.
False - The effect depends on the receptor type activated, not only on the neurotransmitter.
True - Ionotropic receptors directly open ion channels and produce fast responses.
True - NMDA receptors are permeable to Ca²⁺ and play a key role in synaptic plasticity.
False - GABA-A receptors are inhibitory and typically allow Cl⁻ influx.
True - Monoamines mainly modulate neural circuits rather than driving fast synaptic transmission.
False - Endocannabinoids are released from postsynaptic neurons and act retrogradely.
True - Clearance mechanisms terminate signaling and preserve temporal precision.
False - SSRIs block serotonin reuptake, increasing its concentration in the synaptic cleft.
True - Axo-axonic synapses regulate neurotransmitter release rather than postsynaptic voltage.

The nervous system is organized into distinct anatomical and functional divisions. It is composed of interconnected networks that work in tight coordination to support vital, sensory, emotional, cognitive, and behavioral functions.

text:
Central Nervous System (CNS)



The CNS includes:

Brain

Spinal cord




Neurons in the CNS are responsible for:

Sensory processing

Cognitive & Emotional processing
Behavioural output




The CNS is protected by bone, meninges, and cerebrospinal fluid.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Peripheral Nervous System (PNS)


The PNS includes:


Cranial & Spinal nerves

Autonomic NS

Somatic NS




Its main role is communication between the body and the CNS.


Information flows in two directions:

Afferent: From body to CNS
Efferent: From CNS to body

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Somatic nervous system


The somatic nervous system:

Efferent Signals

Skeletal muscles

Voluntary movement



Afferent Signals

Skin

Muscles and Joints

This includes the sense of touch, temperature, pain, and proprioception.



Activity in this system is usually under conscious perception and voluntary control.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Autonomic nervous system


The autonomic nervous system regulates internal physiology.

It controls:

Vital functions (Heart rate, breathing…)
Smooth muscle (Digestion, salivation…)
Glands (Hormones…)



Most autonomic activity occurs without conscious awareness. It is composed of two main branches: Sympathetic and Parasympathetic.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Sympathetic nervous system


The sympathetic nervous system prepares the body for action Fight or Flight Response.

Activation of the sympathetic system typically leads to:

Increased heart rate

Bronchodilation

Reduced digestive activity

Mobilization of glucose




Increase the Arousal level. These effects support physical and cognitive demands.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Parasympathetic nervous system


The parasympathetic nervous system promotes maintenance and recovery. Rest and Digest Response.

Activation of the parasympathetic system typically leads to:

Decreased heart rate

Increased digestive activity

Energy storage

Glandular secretion




Decrease the Arousal level. These effects support recovery and homeostasis.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Major divisions of the brain


From a broad anatomical perspective, the brain is divided into:

Cerebrum (or Forebrain)
Midbrain & Cerebellum
Brainstem (Hindbrain)

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The cerebrum


The cerebrum is divided into two hemispheres (Left and Right) The hemispheres are connected by large bundles of axons (Corpus Callosum).

It is responsible for:

Sensory perception

Voluntary movement

Cognition and language

Conscious awareness




Despite strong similarities, the two hemispheres are not functionally identical.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cerebral Cortex


The outer layer of the cerebrum is the cerebral cortex.

Folding pattern

Gyri Raised ridges of cortex
Sulci Grooves that separate gyri

This pattern increase surface area without increasing volume.


Each hemisphere is subdivided into lobes. The main lobes are: Frontal, Parietal, Temporal, Occipital

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Frontal lobe


The frontal lobe is located anterior to the central sulcus.
It is heavily involved in motor control and high-level cognition.

Primary roles

Voluntary movement

Planning and decision making

Executive control



Effects of damage

Motor dysfunctions
Changes in personality and social behavior

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Parietal lobe


The parietal lobe lies posterior to the central sulcus. It integrates sensory information to construct spatial and bodily representations.

Primary roles

Somatosensory processing

Spatial awareness (Propioception)
Integration of sensory modalities




Effects of damage

Impaired touch perception

Spatial Neglect, especially after right hemisphere damage

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Temporal lobe


The temporal lobe is located laterally, beneath the lateral sulcus. It is closely associated with auditory processing, memory, and emotion.

Primary roles

Auditory perception

Language comprehension

Memory & Emotional processing



Effects of damage

Auditory perception deficits

Impaired language comprehension

Memory & emotional disturbances

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Occipital lobe


The occipital lobe is located at the posterior pole of the brain.
It is primarily dedicated to visual processing.

Primary roles

Visual perception

Processing of shape, motion, and color




Effects of damage

Partial or complete loss of vision

Visual field deficits

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Subcortical structures
Below the Cerebral Cortex we can find also another layer of (Subcortical) structures.

Major subcortical structures include:

Basal nuclei

Hippocampus

Amygdala



They are not visible from the surface but are critical for information processing.

They interact extensively with the cortex.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Basal ganglia
The basal ganglia are a group of interconnected nuclei.
They are best known for their role in:

Movement regulation

Action selection

Habit formation

Damage to these structures disrupts movement without causing paralysis.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Hippocampus


The hippocampus is located in the medial temporal lobe.

It is essential for:

Formation memory and Contextual processing
Spatial navigation

Emotional regulation



Damage may impair the ability to form new long-term memories.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Amygdala


The amygdala is also located in the medial temporal lobe.

It plays a major role in:

Emotional processing

Threat detection

Assigning emotional value to stimuli




Damage to this structure may strongly influence learning and memory under emotional conditions.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Diencephalon


The diencephalon lies beneath the cerebrum.
It serves as a critical interface between cortical and subcortical systems.
Major components include:

Thalamus

Hypothalamus

Epithalamus

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Thalamus


The thalamus is often described as a relay station.
Most sensory information passes through it on the way to cortex.

However, it is not a passive relay. It actively shapes and modulates information flow.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Hypothalamus


The hypothalamus is a group of different nuclei, small but functionally powerful.

It regulates:

Homeostasis

Autonomic nervous system activity

Hormone release

Motivated behaviors




It forms a major link between the nervous and endocrine systems.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Brainstem


The brainstem connects the brain to the spinal cord.
It is essential for survival.

It controls basic functions such as:

Breathing

Heart rate

Sleep and arousal

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Brainstem subdivisions


The brainstem is divided into three major parts:


Midbrain

Pons

Medulla




Each contains nuclei and pathways critical for life.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cerebellum


The cerebellum lies posterior to the brainstem.

It is involved in:

Coordination of movement

Timing

Motor learning




Damage does not prevent movement, but makes it inaccurate and unstable.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Basal nuclei


The basal nuclei are a group of interconnected nuclei. Including the dorsal striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen) and the ventral striatum (nucleus accumbens), the globus pallidus, the ventral pallidum, the substantia nigra, and the subthalamic nucleus.

They are best known for their role in:

Movement regulation

Action selection

Habit formation




Damage to these structures disrupts movement without causing paralysis.

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
The spinal cord
The spinal cord is part of the central nervous system. It serves as the main communication pathway between the brain and the body, through the spinal nerves. It also performs important processing independently of the brain.



Grouped into regions: Cervical, Thoracic, Lumbar, Sacral


Spinal nerves connect to the cord via two roots:

Dorsal root Carries sensory information into the spinal cord
Ventral root Carries motor commands out of the spinal cord

title: Neuroscience of social-cognitive enhancement for well-being and Neural bases of decision processes
text:
Cranial nerves
Cranial nerves are part of the peripheral nervous system. They connect directly to the brain.

Most cranial nerves enter or exit the CNS at the brainstem (except olfactory and optic nerves).


There are 12 pairs of cranial nerves. Numbered using Roman numerals I to XII .


Cranial nerves can be classified by function:

Sensory

Motor

Mixed (sensory and motor)

The Vagus nerve X is unique. It provides extensive parasympathetic innervation to thoracic and abdominal organs. It is a major pathway for autonomic communication between brain and body.

text:
What is a sensory system


A sensory system allows the nervous system to detect and process stimuli from the environment.

Each system is specialized for a particular form of energy or stimulus.

Despite their differences, sensory systems share common organizational principles.

Sensory Transduction
Sensory systems work by converting physical stimuli into neural signals. This process is called transduction.



Sensory receptors: Sensory transduction begins at sensory receptors.


Different receptors are tuned to different stimulus types:

Photoreceptors detect light

Mechanoreceptors detect touch and vibration

Chemoreceptors detect chemicals

Nociceptors detect damaging stimuli
